byline.contributor: Timothy Williams contributed reporting from New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: It has been 15 years since the Rehnquist court began applying the constitutional brakes to assertions of federal power that had seemed unassailable since the New Deal. Its first target was modest, a five-year-old federal statute called the Gun-Free School Zones Act that most people had never heard of, which made it a federal crime to possess a gun within 1,000 feet of a school.
docs.abstract: How a Virginia judge's ruling striking down part of the new health care law takes some Supreme Court precedents too far.
docs.snippet: How a Virginia judge's ruling striking down part of the new health care law takes some Supreme Court precedents too far.

docs.lead_paragraph: With the current emphasis on reining in costs, increasing productivity and improving safety, it's hard not to view the personal amenities offered by certain hospitals with some level of suspicion. While the well-appointed lobbies, personalized meal services and private rooms with a view -- all designed to make hospitals feel un-hospital-like -- can be meaningful to patients, families and even clinicians and staff, few of us have ever acknowledged their role in patient care. Instead, we tend to deride these nonclinical services as fluffy perks at best and frivolous manifestations of profit-driven medicine at worst.

headline.main: A Hospital Room With a View

docs.lead_paragraph: A couple of weeks ago I received my renewal costs for our health insurance coverage. I'm now covering 11 out of 12 workers (one is on his wife's policy). The company -- i.e. me -- pays two-thirds of this cost, the employees pay the rest.

headline.main: My Health Insurance Rates Just Went Down

docs.abstract: My understanding of the health care overhaul is that it will allow me to stop buying insurance for my employees in return for a penalty payment. I may well take that option when it's available.
